Since King Salman appointed Mohammed bin Salman as crown prince of Saudi Arabia in 2017, he has made several moves to consolidate his power in the government. He has replaced a variety of governors and government officials with supporters, making it incredibly difficult for him to be overthrown by any who would oppose him. 
The only reason that Mohammed bin Salman would cease to be crown prince of Saudi Arabia would likely involve the recent situation in which the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi was orchestrated by the government of Saudi Arabia. However, the precedence that has been set in the past regarding Saudi Arabian foreign policy suggests that they are extremely unlikely to respond by taking a powerful position away from a member of the royal family. 
Though it is likely that Mohammed bin Salman will eventually take over the position of King Salman in coming years, the likelihood that it will be by 1 October 2019 is low. This is due to the fact that King Salman only assumed his position in 2015 and due to the relative inexperience that Mohammed bin Salman had when he became crown prince in 2017, he will probably want him to have more experience in state affairs by the time he succeeds him.

Following the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi, there has been backlash against the Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman (MbS) who is claimed by Turkey to have ordered the assassination. Some speculate that MbS' actions have led to attempts to restore an old order focused on the consultation of elders; however, it is unlikely that any actual change will occur as the country's major allies like the US have not called for him to cease his position as Crown Prince. This scandal appears to have had little impact on the ruling House of Saud as it is likely that he will remain in his position since his father, the king, exhausted many of his political resources to anoint him, even alienating his family to make his son crowned prince. The king has also named MbS as the head of a commission charged with reorganizing their intelligence services after the reports of this assassination came to light.

Slight change.   The world seems to have at least partially moved on from the murder of an American journalist, including President Trump.   In the immediate aftermath of the murder, the country's Saudi Vision 2030 project was panned by financers.  However, last week the CEO's of some of the world's largest banks and financial institutions went to Riyadh for a two day conference and seem to have done  a lot of business.  Saudi Arabia has also made deals with Pakistan and China worth billions since the murder.    Moreover, MBS has been meeting with various world leaders, including Putin, who have welcomed him, if not always as warmly as before.    Hence, there is not much chance he will cease to be the crown prince.  Nevertheless, there is a chance.  His father is 83 years old.  If he dies, it is likely, MBS will become king.  The term "crowned prince" means MBS is the designated successor.  The USA Social Security survival tables suggest he would have about an eight percent chance of dying in a year.  I suspect he may have lower probability of death since he likely receives very good health care.   Moreover, there are only four months between now and October 1.  Thus, there is a 2 percent chance of dying-- perhaps even less.   I doubt the distribution for deaths during a year are uniform.   That is, older people did more often so there are probably at least slightly more deaths toward the end of the 83 year than the beginning.    There is also a chance his father could retire and MBS could succeed him.  I think maybe a 10 percent chance given his age and MBS' problems with the murder.

The move to move MBS to the front of succession went against tradition but also solved a serious issue in the line of succession in KSA, so the simultaneous decrees to keep succession within Salman's son's and to consolidate power of security and finance under MBS were probably seen as uncomfortable but reasonable: "...The surprise announcement marks the first time since Saudi Arabia’s first ruler, King Abdul Aziz ibn Saud, that a Saudi monarch has designated his son rather than a brother as his heir apparent.  ...'The reshuffle marks the first real test of the ruling Al Saud family’s ability to manage the inevitable generational shift from the sons of Ibn Saud, to his grandsons,' ...The crown prince’s rise, some analysts said, has been in the works for several months. A series of decrees in April propelled young royals in their 30s into influential diplomatic and national security positions while undermining Mohammed bin Nayef’s power. Together, the appointments represent a generational makeover of a system once dominated by much older and more experienced royals....
https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/saudi-king-names-son-as-new-crown-prince-upending-the-kingdoms-succession-line/2017/06/21/e66db88d-fecc-40fe-a902-7f9afa487de9_story.html?utm_term=.7a10687af762 "...According to the official Saudi Press Agency, the newly announced crown prince was also named deputy prime minister and maintained his post as defence minister. ...The series of decrees also amended Article V of the kingdom's statute of ruling, stipulating that, from now on, only the sons and grandsons of the founding King Faisal Al Saud can be kings and crown princes...."
https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/06/saudi-arabia-appoints-king-salman-son-crown-prince-170621033707437.html "..In his scramble for power, Mohammed has shunted aside rival princes, from powerful figures at the heart of the royal family to little-known cousins on the periphery. At least 11 princes were arrested in November, along with senior business leaders, as part of what the government said was an anti-corruption drive that transformed the Ritz-Carlton hotel in Riyadh into a gilded detention center for some of the kingdom’s most prominent citizens.  Among them were two sons of the late King Abdullah, first cousins of Mohammed who had risen to powerful posts during their father’s reign: Prince Muteib bin Abdullah, then head of the national guard, and Prince Turki bin Abdullah, a former governor of Riyadh.  ...Muteib was stripped of his post, replaced by a relatively obscure relative and released a few weeks after his arrest. But Turki, whom officials had accused of graft related to the construction of Riyadh’s subway line, remains detained nearly a year later...  ...appeared to have two aims — to neutralize Mohammed’s rivals and to seize control of a fund belonging to Abdullah’s foundation, estimated to be tens of billions of dollars. Turki’s chief of staff, also arrested, died while in detention.   ...'The whole of King Abdullah’s family has been completely sidelined,'  ...Two months after the Ritz roundup, the government announced the arrest of an additional 11 princes who authorities said had staged a sit-in at a royal palace in Riyadh to protest the suspension of government payments of their electricity and water bills. ...But people close to Prince Salman bin Abdul Aziz bin Salman, 36, another Mohammed cousin who is not in the direct line of succession, said that he was among those arrested that day and that the government’s story had been a fiction — there had been no protest, and certainly not over the comparatively minor issue of utility bills. Rather, they said, Prince Salman was summoned to the palace in the middle of the night, then beaten and arrested after he arrived. ..."
https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/crown-prince-mohammed-bin-salman-is-chief-of-the-tribe-in-a-cowed-house-of-saud/2018/10/30/f6fa4b68-d946-11e8-aeb7-ddcad4a0a54e_story.html?utm_term=.e98617bcc7ea "...Fourteen current and former senior U.S. officials told NBC News that intelligence shows Prince Mohammed bin Salman — often referred to by his initials MBS — blocked his mother from seeing his father, King Salman, more than two years ago and has kept her away from him as the young prince rapidly amassed power.  Prince Mohammed, a key ally of the Trump White House, has concocted various explanations of his mother's whereabouts over the years, such as that she's out of the country receiving medical treatment, so King Salman would not know his son has been behind her continued absence, the current and former officials said.  U.S. officials interviewed for this story believe, based on several years of intelligence, that MBS took action against his mother because he was concerned that she opposed his plans for a power grab that could divide the royal family and might use her influence with the king to prevent it. The officials said MBS placed his mother under house arrest at least for some time at a palace in Saudi Arabia, without the king's knowledge....
https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/u-s-officials-saudi-crown-prince-has-hidden-his-mother-n847391 List of Decrees: https://www.thenational.ae/world/saudi-royal-decrees-announcing-prince-mohammed-bin-salman-as-the-new-crown-prince-1.93194 I think it's notable that there has not been a deputy Crown Prince named in line of succession after MBS
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deputy_crown_prince There have been rumors since January that King Salman is doing public events without MBS and that a rift has been growing between them, particularly because King Salman is unhappy at the Saudi reputation re: Khashoggi.  Furthermore, with the police power and money largely behind MBS, there isn't much the Saud family can do that would maintain stability and maintain the general power of the family over one particular faction in any cohesive way except (I think) to wait until King Salman limits MBS' power or King Salman dies and the succession to MBS has to be ratified by the Allegiance Council:
"...some members of Saudi Arabia’s ruling family are agitating to prevent Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman from becoming king, three sources close to the royal court said. ...Dozens of princes and cousins from powerful branches of the Al Saud family want to see a change in the line of succession but would not act while King Salman - the crown prince’s 82-year-old father - is still alive, the sources said. They recognize that the king is unlikely to turn against his favorite son, known in the West as MbS. ...Rather, they are discussing the possibility with other family members that after the king’s death, Prince Ahmed bin Abdulaziz, 76, a younger full brother of King Salman and uncle of the crown prince, could take the throne, according to the sources.  Prince Ahmed, King Salman’s only surviving full brother, would have the support of family members, the security apparatus and some Western powers, one of the Saudi sources said.  ...He was one of only three people on the Allegiance Council, made up of the ruling family’s senior members, who opposed MbS becoming crown prince in 2017, two Saudi sources said at the time.   ...When the king dies or is no longer be able to rule, the 34-member Allegiance Council, a body representing each line of the ruling family to lend legitimacy to succession decisions, would not automatically declare MbS the new king.  Even as crown prince, MbS would still need the council to ratify his ascension, one of the three Saudi sources said. While the council accepted King Salman’s wish to make MbS crown prince, it would not necessarily accept MbS becoming king when his father dies, especially given that he sought to marginalize council members.
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-saudi-khashoggi-royals-exclusive/exclusive-after-khashoggi-murder-some-saudi-royals-turn-against-kings-favorite-son-idUSKCN1NO2KP
https://www.trtworld.com/middle-east/could-prince-ahmed-bin-abdulaziz-replace-crown-prince-mohammed-bin-salman-21832 I agree with the Foreign Policy author that King Salman is unlikely to remove MBS from his position, or if he does, to do it in line with the direction of succession he has been moving in.  I don't think he will publicly chastise MBS nor publicly retreat on his own policy measures, but I don't think he has a lot of options to address the power issue either directly or indirectly.  He does seem to be unhappy with the state of affairs currently.  
"...It is unclear from recent official press statements about the king and the prince’s activities whether Prince Mohammed has been absent from all of the high-profile events, but the prince has not appeared in any recent photographs or press statements, apart from a report that he spoke to Japan’s prime minister Shinzo Abe over the phone last week.  ...Though Prince Mohammed has missed meetings before, a source familiar with the workings of the royal court said there was genuine surprise at some of the ‘no-shows’ in the last fortnight.  The king is understood to have been particularly displeased with his son’s absence from the cabinet meeting on Tuesday, during which the king discussed the many challenges facing the kingdom.  In a two-hour address, the king is understood to have raised concerns over alleged lost investments into Saudi Arabia.  It led to a demand that all major future financial decisions would, for the time being, need the king’s personal approval, according to the account given to the Guardian. The decision was considered effective immediately and concerned major investments by the kingdom and other contracts.  ...Tensions are said to have flared up after Prince Mohammed announced two important personnel decisions hours after the king left Saudi Arabia for an official visit to Egypt.  The promotion of Princess Reema bint Bandar bin Sultan to serve as Saudi ambassador to the US, and the promotion of Prince Mohammed’s brother, Khalid bin Salman, to the ministry of defence, were allegedly announced without the king’s approval or knowledge.  The decrees to make the changes were signed by the crown prince in his role as “deputy king”, which some experts said was exceedingly rare.
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/mar/18/saudi-crown-prince-allegedly-stripped-of-some-authority I don't know what a satisfactory solution would be, but King Salman doesn't seem so mentally weak and confused yet that he would give over his power to his "deputy king" when he's still King and disagrees with what or the way things are done.  But I think his generation feels more strongly in the democratic nature of their oligarchy than in the singularity or stability of one faction or vision, even if stability and focus was King Salman's goal in the decrees that brought MBS front and center.   I also agree with the Foreign Policy author in his argument that the Saud family has rallied to the throne in times of crisis.  But I think there is an effort to find ways to support the throne without supporting MBS to its succession.  And I think the argument / rumor that King Salman's brother be a likely or even the most likely replacement is strong (it's a return to tradition prior to King Salman's decrees in 2017) but probably an undesirable or risky move because it would also undermine the King's authority in making those decrees.  But the succession has seen enough recent changes it's hard to tell how sacrosanct it is.  Maybe more important is to not reverse an authoritative move.  I don't have a deep knowledge of political maneuvering in Saudi Arabia, but some of the slowness to change seems to me to be a result of the "regulatory" nature of royal authority as opposed to a written body of law.  People can interpret changes in a more modern way but are bound in some ways (as has been very clear in KSA) by the expectations and understanding of tradition vs. need.  The family is slow to change because the people and culture are slow to change mindsets.  I think MBS has been so successful because he is good at using traditional power mechanisms while tying them to themes of modernization and progress.  King Salman won't go back on MBS unless he can do so by moving forward in the succession / family power structure, and the royal family won't go against the King or rebel against the power of the state (MBS) without Salman taking the lead.  If there's a way out where the pressure won't hold, they seem likely to be able to find it, and there seems to be enough consensus across the family to make it a possibility at least. https://foreignpolicy.com/2019/03/11/mohammed-bin-salman-is-here-to-stay/ So I think it's a waiting game, and I think October is too soon for the pace of politics from either King Salman or the Saud family / Alliegiance Council.  They need to maintain the power of the traditions without upsetting them even more.  Limiting MBS' power at this point is more crucial than ousting him, I would think.  But no significant enough moves to limit MBS' power publicly have been made (as were made 6 months or more before the previous succession changes) to make it likely that there is a shift being planned or already in process.  And if 6-8 months is how long those moves have taken most recently, it seems that October is pushing the timeline for a major succession change.  Things may seem desperate, but I think the Saud family doesn't let anything seem that desperate (even if it may be) because it would undermine their authority.  I think Salman naming a deputy crown prince would be the most likely sign that there is a move/plan to change, or at least curtail the overweening power of, MBS. List for future reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allegiance_Council

Khashoggi story was never going to get MbS out of the running; Al Saud family rules KSA, and foreign critics have little power there. I don't know if that's true, but in any case the base rate for such events is low. Let's give it 5%. So that's at least a 6.7% chance that MbS ascends to throne. I round it up to 10% to account for the possibility of Salman Al Saud passing on the crown to MbS while still alive. To come up with a baseline I looked at Crown Prince history a bit ... 11 of them prior to MBS.  The mean tenure was 7.1 years.  6 of 11 became king (surprised it wasn't more).  Two died in waiting as old men, two resigned, and one was deposed.  MBS is a young guy so let's consider a 3/11 chance over an entire tenure of being shown the door discounting his demise this year.  Let's go with 3/11 divided by 7.1 as the historic chance per year a Crown Prince gets the boot. That gives us 3.8%.  That seems low given the current headlines but there is always intrigue it seems there  ... I'll round up to 5%.  Now for the odds he'll become king ... The average chance per year for the six who became king was 12.6%.  Considering that the current king is 83 with health issues let's double that ... 25%

BECOMING KING: For this to happen, King Salman would need to abdicate the throne or die. Given that Saudi Arabia doesn't have a history of Kings stepping down before their death, thereby precluding this scenario, let's talk death.  King Salman is 82 years old. As someone else noted previously: using historical data on Saudi Arabia life expectancy, the likelihood of dying between the ages of 80 and 84, as well as between the ages 75 to 79, is 45.7% and 30.5%, respectively (when linearly extrapolated to 2019). [1] Given that this probability covers a period of 4 years (ages 80 to 84) and the forecast question covers a period of approximately 1 year (now until October 2019), this places the average likelihood of death over the next year at approximately 3.8% (45.7 - 30.5 / 4). It's probably slightly higher given that it's in the latter half of the 80 to 84 range and the likelihood of death is not normally distributed, but rather skewed higher as age increases. Here's where things get complicated. As someone pointed out, King Salman had a stroke in 2010 (8 years ago). A medical study suggests that the cumulative risk of death in the 10 years following a stroke is enhanced by a factor of 1.9 due to a greater risk of cardiovascular-related deaths [2; Table 2, Column 3, Row 7]. This seems compatible with his genes; his two oldest sons, Fahd and Ahmad, have already died as a result of heart problems. [3] Also, King Salman's alleged diagnosis of mild dementia increases the likelihood of death. One medical study suggests that it increases death by a factor of approximately 1.7. [4; Table 1, Columns 2 & 3, Row 3]. At any rate, the combination of both does not bode well for King Salman's health. However, he's likely receiving the best care, relative to the average Saudi citizen, which attenuates the likelihood of death.  So in summary, the average likelihood of death would be 3.8% given his age. Incorporating his medical history and top-of-the-line healthcare, this increases by a factor of approximately 2.5.  Therefore, I'm going to place the probability of King Salman's death, and the subsequent transition of power to MBS, at 10% -- although, I didn't plan on it becoming an even 10. NOT BECOMING KING: This is much more challenging to ascertain.  Of the 12 named crown princes, only 1 has been substituted, placing the probability at approximately 8%. [5] However, it was MBS who plotted to remove MBN, thereby granting him the status of crown prince. [6] Moreover, given the consolidation of his power and immense influence in Saudi politics, I do not believe he will be relieved from power. Finally, I do not believe recent events will compel any change; resource-rich monarchies, out of any regime type, are the most impervious to public opinion. Therefore, I'm placing this probability at 1%. This consequently means the remaining probability falls under "No" -- 89%. Thoughts? [1] http://apps.who.int/gho/data/?theme=main&vid=61440

MBS's rapid rise to power and the growing consolidation of power in a smaller circle of people has inevitably angered some senior princes. However, his position is still strong. This owes a lot to his consolidation of power over the last two years. His control over key institutions such as the Interior Ministry, National Guard, and Defence Ministry, in particular, bolsters his position. But his position owes even more to the Saudi ruling family’s strong emphasis on continuity and projecting an image of internal cohesion.  His rapid ascent to power has already pushed the boundaries of the country’s succession process. The Al Saud are well aware that a complete breakdown of this process would weaken their legitimacy and risk bringing about far more serious political instability.  With the King reported to be in poor health, abdication during 2019 is looking increasingly likely.
